remixed_from.author: zeke7237
remixed_from.title: Openscad modules for Open Rail components

description.text: The two spacers of this Thing serve to combine a pair of OpenBeams and OpenRails into a 15x40mm rail system.

I printed at 0.2 layer height, in ABS, with 100% fill. You can adjust the length of the blocks in the OpenSCAD code, but 20mm looked about right. I use one pair of blocks at every other OpenRail screw slot. The top block is sized to take a pair of M3x10 screws and nuts; the bottom block takes a pair of M3x5 . The bottom block has a removable support across the slot where the nut is placed. It rips off easily. Once that's removed, with a pair of needle nosed pliers and a bit of patience, you can place a nut in the slot and it will stay there while you insert the block onto the beams. Inserting one point of the nut, then twisting the other side down to seat it works best (see pic). The OpenSCAD code incorporates the code from http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:45913 in it's entirety. Uncommenting the indicated lines in the code will display OpenBeams and OpenRails in proper relation to the OpenBeamRailSlide blocks. In the last photo, it's shown with a printed MakerSlide Lens Carriage http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:12512 but this was just done for testing the slide; the printed plate is not rigid enough for practical use.

title: feeder for "Ultimaker 2 Rail System"
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
reinforced version of my previous feeder, adapted for use with the "Ultimaker2 Rail System".
After hundreds of printing hours on my feeder the hook got a little loose, so I decided not just to replace it but also to strengthen it a little. Since using the U2RS means you don't have the size restrictions you would have at the backplate, I added a few millimeters here and there, and merged the body with a mounting plate. Also modified the hook shape a little to have more surface area touching the main arm. My advice is to use any material you like (PLA, XT, ABS), but to use PLA for the body. If you have some wear on the body you might get some particles in your bowden/heater, you don't want ABS/XT in there when printing at lower PLA temperatures. Search for "U2RS" to find other parts of the rail system. printed - layer 0,1 - Fill 100% - speed 35mm/s
you need to move the knurled wheel a little towards the motor, just so much the fillament will be nice in the middle of it. if you want to get the designfiles of this feeder you can download them here;
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/feeder-for-ultimaker-2-rail-system ultimaker2 rail system ;
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:430899 my original feeder ;
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:378939 wich was mostly based on the "mother of all UM2 feeders" ;
https://www.youmagine.com/designs/alternative-um2-feeder-version-two edit 1/2015 ; Body update, added a little mass just around the bearing wheel, to have a bit more guidance for the fillament while using flexible fillament. Just did the UM extrusion test succesfully at 230 celsius to 8,5 mm3/s using (semi)flexible Makerpoint MP flex 45. Take this one when you want to use this feeder, probably no need to upgrade for most people using the V1.

description.text: EDIT: After using this to clean my mighty hobbed bolts, I worry that small bits of brass wire might find their way into the extruder. I have resorted to using a toothbrush for Hob Nobbing.  You have been warned.

I found that the perfect tool for cleaning the mighty hobbed bolt is a a brass bore brush used for cleaning firearms. Just set the extruder to extrude nothing for 50mm and spin the brush in the cuts on the bolt. One problem is that it is too short to comfortably hold while you mung out the fine teeth of the Hob. Hobbing?

This handy little adapter allows you to screw it into a 1/4" hex that will plug into your favorite screwdrivey handle thingamajig. The width of this little gizmacci is LESS than 1/4" across the flats- yet it is still too big to fit into my screwdrivey handle thingamajig without sanding/filing. Feel free to experiment. I won't be offended. Share.

Oh, I discovered that the tension on the hobbed bolt needs to be vastly less than what I initially thought. If you're chewing up your fillyment, back it off a bit. AND clean out the pixie dust from the teeth.

The hole is 3.5mm; the threads on the bore brush measured about 4mm. This is not QUITE big enough to just thread the bore brush into the adapter without some profanity and/or blood. In any case, you will probably opt for a different size bore brush, with a different thread - measure carefully. I chose .32 caliber.

This is a fan mount for a centrifugal computer cooling fan that will clip right on the back of your prusa's x-carriage. The mount keeps the bearings secured in case you are like me and your clips lost their grip on the bearings due to vibration stresses.

Print out fan mount. Find a 30mm thick fan(I found mine in an old dell desktop. It was used to cool the cpu.) Slide a 40mm m3 screw through the mounting holes, securing the fan to the mount. Now simply clip the assumbly onto the back of your x carriage, wire it up and you're GOLDEN.
FYI make sure the fan clearance is sufficient over the print bed. Mine has a good millimeter of clearance. Less may work as well

title: Z Axis Clamp for End stop

description.text: This is nothing special but needed a clamp to mount a adjustment screw for the Z End Stop. This Thing is a derivative from AlephObjects Z Clamp included with their printer but I just saw a picture of it and made what I needed for my machine. And if someone can find a use for it on their machine, that's great!

You need to print one of each:
1 - Z Clamp
1 - Z Block - ( if you need it)
1 - 4mm Socket Head screw cap Its for a 10mm rod I printed at 90% infill, 2 shells, 3 skirt if you are printing with ABS.
The cap fits a 4mm socket head screw so the inner hex pin inside it really does nothing as its pretty snug. Use a M4 nut in holder top and bottom of screw into clamp. I didn't use a spring like the one from Aleph but you could. Depending on your printer you may need to bore out the holes or create ones where you need them. My first go with creating something, I used Sketchup and ran the stl's thru Netfabb before posting. Parts Needed:
1 - 4mm x 25mm SHCS
2 - M4 x .7 Nuts
2 - 3mm x 25mm SHCS or suitable
2 - M3 x .5 Nuts You will need some sort of end stop, I am using mechanical ones.

This is a modular dolls' house that can be arranged in several combinations. I had a lot of fun drawing the rooms and the furniture.
I never had a dolls' house, I used to build it with paper when I was a little kid, and it was one of my favourite fantastic game scenarios.

Print the parts you prefer, there are 8 different pieces, the first 5 files are the square rooms, the last 3 are he triangle rooms/roof parts. Everything can be printed without support material. The chairs have thin supports among the legs. You can decide to keep it, or cut it away. The sofa is a derivative of this file: http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:4872 In some rooms there are "nails" on the wall where kids can hang the clock, the mirror, or the painings. Or maybe the doll's dress. I thought not to waste too much plastic designing these pieces, I also suggest an infill of 0.2 (20%). The furniture has tiny parts so I don't think it is suitable for children younger than 3 years, while I think the rooms could be ok for them too.

title: My BB Filled LM8UU Type Bearings

description.text: These bearings take 4.5 mm steel BBs. (Copper might work, but I have heard that they may cause problems due to the metal differences.) I printed these on a Printrbot Simple in PLA at .25 layer height and 10% Infill. (I have also tried to print these on a Makerbot Replicator 2 at the Low Resolution with 10% infill, but they had a much lower tolerance. Ie, they turned out very tight and it took a long time to wear the BBs in to their races before smooth travel was possible.) Dimensions: Short: 23 mm High, 22 mm Outer Diameter Long: 48 mm High, 22 mm Outer Diameter Inner holes are 8 mm in diameter. (This should work on 5/16” rods as well.) After printing you may want to use an Exacto knife or 8 mm drill to make certain the hole will give clearance for the rod as the plastic tends to swell into it a bit when printed.) The Combined Version is the same size as the Short with the addition of parts to allow it to be used on a Prusa i3 Rework Y Bed. When assembling the combined version I suggest placing the BBs in the races, placing the top and bottom on a flat surface and then using a clamp to press them together. (Attempting to twist them together may result in breaking the mounting brackets.) The Short uses 16 BBs. The Long uses 32 BBs. I really liked the concept of using BBs for the bearings like in http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:28905, but my attempts to print them out failed. I tried to use Netfabb Basic to repair the file, but still was ending up with 739 flipped triangles. So I began to design this version instead. One of the things I was hoping to do is be able to create a design that could allow me to modify in order to create odd sized linear bearings. Tearing apart inkjets and laser printers I have found many of the rods are 5, 7 and 9 mm sizes which are not typical linear bearing sizes. I’ve included the original FreeCAD model files in case you want to also modify the design to fit your needs.

comments.text: I have been trying to use the combined ones on my Prusa i3 build for the Y bed. I would say they are more noisy than the bought LM8UU bearings. They might be less so if I used some PTFE based grease (or any type that won't harm the plastic). I've been using Blaster brand The Dry Lube spray for lubricant but you can still hear the BBs as they roll against the rod. As I printed these in PLA, another issue that may come up is the friction/heat problem if your prints are long. I am hoping the grease would help keep the BBs from heating up too much to cause melting/warping of the plastic. With the other designs, they're not drop in replacements for LM8UUs since they have a much larger outer diameter. I was thinking perhaps of using them in a Smartrap or Fabrap type of device, but would have to re-design the parts so these would work. Also, I think I may have the number of BBs wrong for the long ones. I think it is more than the 24 so just keep stuffing them in until the races are full. (Maybe more like 28-32.)

title: Parametric Y Plate Bushings, IGUS Style, for Prusa I3, and variants with Solidworks 2014 source
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
I decided I had enough of the lousy loud LM8UU bearings (bearings are already falling out of my Chinese made ones) so I put my LM8UU support brace and my IGUS styled bushings together to form an all in one unit.
.
IMine are printed in ABS but I would have loved to have done them in Nylon.
.
The parametric parts are for the inner diameter as well as the number of teeth.
For those without access to Solidworks 2014, or greater, I have included a six and an eight tooth version (I use the six tooth version).
.
This will lift your bed up ever so slightly as I noticed that when using bushings, or bearings, it doesn't give much room for wearing down and was way too close for comfort for bushings. I don't want my 22 dollar rod being scratched up by the Aluminum Y plate if it decides to wear down mid print and I am not around.

Print this with 30% infill and do it slowly (20-30mm/s) for the external parameters (the rest can be fast).
Be sure to grease this as I used silicone grease but silicone spray may work though the grease stays put and gets inside the grooves.

description.text: It is what it says. Created using OpenSCAD and InkScape.

A fully 3D-printable rotating stand for filament spools, designed to be easily made without the need for fasteners such as screws, nuts, shafts, glue, etc. Every single component in this spool holder comes right from your 3D printer's filament.
The spool holder's spindle is shaped to fit the vast majority of commonly used filament spools with shaft holes ranging from 16 mm to 62 mm in diameter. It is also compatible with spool-less filament coils.
The spindle which holds the spool's weight rotates on its own roller wheels, which makes it turn effortlessly.
The spool holder included an arm for filament guide tubes of both common sizes 1.75 mm and 3.0 mm. The arm also contains a pocket for inserting a piece of sponge which acts a a filament filter - thus keeping the filament clean and lubricated.

• Easy to 3D print
  • Needs no glue or fasteners
  • All parts can be 3D-printed
  • Fits almost any filament spool size
  • Has built-in filament filter!
  • Can also hold spool-less filament coils
  • Base versions available for standing on flat surfaces or fit on extruded aluminium profiles.
    Next time you need a new filament spool holder, just 3D-print one! :)

Please also see our Universal Cantilevered Spool Holder for 3D printers
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2297303

description.header: 3D-print only what you need while testing!
description.text: As you already realise this image is not the entire filament spool stand (http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:508896). It shows a crucial part and best-practice related to 3D-printing. As with any product development one never knows exactly from start how things will fit together. Depending on what 3D printer and settings you use, this spool stand will take a few hours to print. It is therefore unnecessary to 3D-print lengthy product iterations just to find out that you need to change a portion of the whole design. The 3D-prints shown in this image represent the parts of the model with fittings which we wanted to give a test-run before we defined the final dimensions. Therefore we cut away the smallest possible volume surrounding the fittings and 3D-printed them in a fraction of the time which otherwise would have taken hours and hours to find out. After measuring the results we could adjust the CAD-model correspondently and get perfect fittings when 3D-printing the final model. This procedure is perfect for testing overhangs, fittings, crucial dimensions, material consumption cost, etc. So in other words.... don't waste time and filament! :)

comments.text: Hi, the design looks really good, but I have a problem. I have already printed amost all parts.... All of tehm fits perfect, teh thing rollls with no problems. The filament "escapes" to the inside, not to the outside of the spool holder. Any solutions?

comments.text: Thank you Tinchus2009 for your comment. We are very glad you liked the spool holder. Handling loose coils of filament is always a bit of a challenge. To help you we have updated the things list here and uploaded two new versions of the files in which you can insert a loop of filament also onto the top part of the holding arms. Please see this image as a reference to the filament loop. http://thingiverse-production-new.s3.amazonaws.com/renders/7a/e4/59/45/c1/Universal_stand-alone_filament_spool_holder__Fully_3D-printable__v14_preview_featured.jpg

comments.text: I already printed those parts from the very begining. The filament loop prevents the filament to escape to the outside, but the problem is that actually the filament when it is pulled by the printer, it tends to escape to the inside of the spool.
comments.author: CreativeTools

comments.text: Please make sure to download the new files below. They did not exist from the very beginning and we modified them specifically for the purpose of inserting a loop of filament - which avoids the filament from escaping inwards.
comments.author: Tinchus2009

comments.text:
I Did print those new version files. It doesn't work with spool less laywood rolls
I have checkes everythiong and I have printed all parts and tested them. For other spools the design works really noche, but for lywood rolls... forget it. The problem is the orientation: there is no way of pulling from the filament in an horizontal way. The filament just stretchs and adjust around the spool. When the extruder pulls from the filamet sometimes the filament is pulled, sometimes the filament starts to adjust around the spoll and sometimes it adjusts itselsf so hard that it breaks (laywood is very sensitive to this. So people: great design but it doesnt work with spool less laywood filaments.

comments.text: I tried this out for the first time on my Wilson.  I don't know how others have found this but with vinyl tubing (water tubing) as a guide I got too much friction to easily pull filament from the spool mounted horizontally above the extruder.  Maybe with Teflon tubing it would work, but I think a vertical or even a diagonal guide would work better than a horizontal one, it's simply asking too much for the filament to make a 90 degree turn on a dime from the spool down to the extruder.  Probably would need a Teflon roller above a vertical guide (or a Teflon roller on the side of a horizontal one) for this to work right.  I can hear my extruder strain to yank on the filament.  The spool turns easy enough, it's the friction of the filament in the guide.
comments.author: scharkalvin

comments.text: Filament entanglement is a very common cause of air prints (3D printer extruder can't pull the filament when it gets stuck in a knot). The most common underlying reason is that the filament tip at some stage becomes loose and get twined. In the long run this causes a knot to form.

author: tc_fea

description.text:
Custom cooler fan nozzle and funnel. Suitable for cooling fans with dimentions 40x40mm (like the Velleman K8200).
Many of the cooler fan nozzles i have found online did have too small exit diameter, which restricted and caused poor airflow.
The wide nozzle exit on this design, in combination with intenal guide fins, the cone, and the intake funnel gives a nice steady airflow. Design considerations:
Thin walls - No need for extra solid construction, after all it is just supposed to funnel air. The two different parts has no steep overhangs so it is possible to print whithout support. Don't waste plastic. Make it quicker to print.
Nozzle exit cross section is approximately the same area as the fan cross section. - don't restrict airflow.
Nozzle cone - avoid creating turbulence.
Internal guide fins connected to nozzle cone - hold cone in place and fight turbulence.
Funnel - restrict air escaping in the small gap between fan blades and fan wall. Fight turbulence.
Funnel exit and nozzle intake are same diameter as fan diameter - do not restrict airflow.
GNU-GPL license - make it possible for others to customize model for their own use.
Supply SCAD file - make it easy for others to customize model for their own use.

This part is a backup fan for Hot end Heat sink.
It happens that each fan has a lifespan of a few 10000's hours.
After a while due to lifespan or dust or what ever else, your fans will start making some noise.
This is an indicator that your fan might get stuck in a near future and that you might need to oil the bearing or change your fan.
With full or half metal hot ends, the fan for the heat sink is MANDATORY. If it fail before printing, it's not a big deal you can change it before starting you hot end.
But if it fails during a print you will break something on your printer as your hot end will get jammed by your expended filament. This backup fan is made to be a secondary fan in case the first one stopped or get stuck somehow. It should allow at least to end you print without breaking anything and keep your heat sink "cold". To be used on top of this part:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:211597

It's been almost a year, but I decided to make another set of themed 3D cookie cutters, similar to my 3D Christmas cookie cutters, http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:207406. This set includes a ghost, a pumpkin, a jack-o-lantern, a black cat, and a haunted house. They all worked great, except for the jack-o-lantern which ended up breaking during assembly. I modified the stl for that one to make it stronger and easier to go together.
As a warning, there has been some concern over the food safety of 3D printed plastics. For all of these cookies, i cut the dough with a layer of plastic wrap between the cookies and the dough. It still worked, but there was a slight loss of detail.

So in order to actually assemble these cookies, you need to select the right recipe. You need cookies that will maintain their shape when baking and that won't rise too much. For these cookies I used a different recipe that turned out great.
http://www.cooks.com/rec/story/202/
When making the cookies roll the dough out to a little under .25 inches thick. When you assemble the cookies, you might want to cut the slots with a serrated knife like a steak knife or a paring knife to open then up a little bit. Just kind of shave down the edges so that the cookies fit together nicely. Also, most of the shapes can just slide together, but you might want to use some icing to hold them together if yours don't come out right.
Broke mine, I manage to design a new one with some modifications.

I want to quickly and easily throw together different types of space frames. Basically, I need adult sized tinker toys, with enough accessories that I can have structural support, can throw on some electronics, etc. This set of things is designed for the construction of rectangular frames. There is a vertex, a pass-thru, and a stackable. There is also a shelf piece which will take 1/8" shelving, whether acrylic or plywood, or whatever. UPDATE: 18 Dec 2010
Added cubon.scad and connectcommon.scad so you can do your own designs. My explorations are towards creating enclosures that do not utilize any fasteners. So, friction fit is good. Perhaps a dab of glue, a piece of tape. If you really want to, you can drill a screw hold here and there for added stability. As it is, the things require a little bit of support in the holes.

1) Design your rectangle based space frame
2) Print a few vertices to satisfy your design
3) Cut some rods according to your design
4) Place rods into appropriate pieces
5) Rejoice! This particular design fits 5/16" rods. You can modify to fit whatever rod size you have. You can use smooth steel rod, threaded rod, wooden dowels, bamboo sticks...

I converted emmett's cube gear to a SolidWorks 2014 files from the original STL files. There are two separate files for the larger gears. One is designed to pattern the text on all 3 sides of the cube gear and the other is customizable on all 3 sides. I've placed all components in an assembly file and mated them so the gears turn in sync. old style pins are included but not in the assembly. Note both short and* long pins are saved as configurations in the pin part file. Also note there is a mate in the assembly that keeps the gears from turning. this must be suppressed or deleted to turn the gears.   
Newer version of the cube gear using the updated pins can be found under the files marked v2.0

title: One piece arm for PL2Q Hugin Quadcopter

description.text:
I decided to make full use of my FlashForge Creator Pro bed so I combined the arm and motor mount into one piece. Then I laid it horizontally on the bed which makes the arm much stronger, and because I eliminated the connection point it is lighter too. Since I had four Ipower out runners (iBM 2217Q) motors laying around I made holes for that motor.
If you have a FlashForge Creator Pro just use the correct files. Note:12/19/14 I have strengthened the arms with a couple of bands (not that any ever broke. I also created one without mounting holes for those that have different kinds of motors.

author: 3dAl

title: Two Color D20 with Flush Numbers

description.text: This model has different looking numbers than the 8 bit one that's out there.  I also wanted the numbers to be flush to the outside so it would be easier to clean up.  I created the ring around the bottom of the files so you can easily line them up.
Just import the two separate files and center.  The ring segments at the bottom of the die will align the two parts together with no guesswork.

Archive model. Not recommended for repetition.
New extruder: https://www.thingiverse.com/thing:2658691

Direct extruder for my new 3D printer project.
Fits for Nema16/Nema17 stepper motors with planetary gearboxes any gear ratios.
My stepper motor is Nema 17 with planetary gearbox 5:1 gear ratio.
(part # 17HS13-0404S-PG5 from StepperOnline).
Nema 16 motor (part # 16HS13-0604S-PG5) has an identical size gearbox, except shaft diameter (8mm).
I'm going to use short-distance E3D hotend, so the bottom side has the mounting groove.
Lever has a placement for the dust filter sponge.
Mendel mounting plate model (not tested): http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:511681

You need also:
  • Extruder gear (feeder roller) bore ø6mm (my was ø5mm, just ream it up to 6mm).
  • V625ZZ ball bearing (V-grooved).
  • 4pcs bolts M3x30mm (would be better if one of them would have a screw-thread just on 8-10mm (I've made one on lathe from M4 bolt).
  • 1pcs bolt M3x20mm with M3 hex nut.
  • 5pcs M3 plain washers.
  • 2pcs 40mm countersunk head screws for fan (40x40x20).
  • 17mm shaft ø5mm for ball bearing.
  • Spring ø7.5 x 8.1-15mm. My from dryer clips (Ikea PRESSA series).
  • Needs insert a little PTFE tube ø4mm under the gear as a filament guide.

title: Mendel Max 2.0 Hall Effect Sensor Holder

description.text:
Hi all, I thought I would share:
I broke off the little magnet-sensor for the Z-height endstop on my MM2, and seeing that no one in the world except for RepRapDiscount sells those sensors, I had to order 3x just to fix the 1x I broke. No worries, except that the mounting plate did not fit the new sensor. Here is an .STL and Fusion360 file to adapt the sensors found here:
http://www.reprapdiscount.com/electronics/18-set-hall-endstops3-pieces.html
All you need is some M3x12mm screws to go through the holes (no nut needed unless you want it to be very secure). Also had to solder a new connector wire since the old sensor had them hardwired. Also needed to replace the magnet from the old sensor with the shipped ones as they are stronger and the one I had installed was facing the wrong way.

title: Fuji Instax Photo Frame

description.text:
Forget Instagram! Here's a simple little picture frame for your Fuji Instax Mini or Polaroid 300 photos.  
This frame is printed in one piece. The photos slot in from behind, and are securely held without damaging them. The support "beams" could be used to attach fridge magnets or double sided tape, or the frame can be hung over a nail.  
The photos are held in place by grooves along each edge, which are printed as 45° overhangs to avoid any dramas.
This file needs hardly any fill; I used 10% honeycomb. For the top and bottom fill I recommend using Concentric because it looks wonderful on the front of the frame - rectilinear is too busy.

title: ~500 mm Honeycomb Quadcopter frame
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
A larger variant of Dennis Baldwin's mini quadcopter honeycomb frame, which can be found at http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:463579
I had this printed in ABS at 30% infill. Some minor filing was needed to make the parts fit together, but it's very light and flies really well.
In the future, I may upload a version 2.0 where the parts fit together a bit better.

-1 3d printed large honeycomb frame (with some CA glue to hold parts together)
-4 Sunnysky 2212-13 980 Kv Brushless motors
-4 30A Ipeaka ESCs
-1 Naza M-Lite flight controller (GPS not required)
-1 Turnigy 3S 3300 mAh 30C Lipo Battery
-4 8045 Hobbyking SF props (9" or 10" props also work well, but I like the 8" props)
-1 Power distribution board of your choice
-1 TX/RX combo of your choice
This frame supports different sized flight controllers:
-Smaller ones like the CC3D or the MultiWii Flip (inside center mounting holes)
-Bigger ones like KK Multicopter (outside center mounting holes)
-Others like Naza lite (as suggested for this build) or APM 2.6 with some foam mounting tape or velcro

Machined from aluminum. Cement in 2 X 2W 10 ohm for normal power range 24W, or 2x 6 ohm for high power 48W. In order to use 48W mode, you must have an EC that will drive 12 @ 5A
I use a mixture of fire clay, sodium silicate and a small amount of water to make my own cement. Apply liberally insert resistor and wipe off excess. should be well wetted. power it up on 1A for 10 min then 30 min on 0.5A to activate Sodium silicate hardener. 
Ceramic cement works well too, i just cant seem to find a good supply.

A centerpiece projector that will project the constellation Canis Major down onto a table. I made this for the annual dinner of the Auckland Astronomical Society. Will have one of these on each table, because I can't find any good astronomy-themed centerpieces. Follow the steps on the instructions page, It's actually quite simple to make. The print files should be good to go. They should be correctly scaled and self-supported, so no supports or rafts are required. You can use the battery holder for anything you like, it's not customized exclusively to this projector, except it's got a very slight indent on it so you can tell where the LED goes. You can also get the battery holder on its own. Huge thank you to threonin for the idea and NotSoSolid for the battery holder base

This is so simple I can even do it with my terrible electronics prowess. The print files should be good to go. They should be correctly scaled and self-supported, so no supports or rafts are required. You will need:
  • The 3 files printed
  • A CR2032 Battery
  • A Super Flux 4 pin LED
    • Instructions:

  • Thread some thin wire through the holes on the battery holder. The wires on the + (positive) side should go through the center holes to touch the battery, then loop up and through the back holes to the other side.

  • Glue down the LED onto the LED impression on the - (negative) side of the battery holder, then glue down the positive side (the side without the LED impression) of the battery holder into the lid.

  • You will need to solder the contacts of the wire onto the LED. While I tried to give a solderless solution, it just wasn't happening I'm afraid.
    Note: Try not to melt the battery holder with your soldering gun

  • Pop the battery in (make sure the + etched on the holder matches the positvie side of your battery

  • Pop the lid on and voila, projector!

This is meant for keeping the belts parallel when swapping to a 20 tooth pulley on the Rigidbot. I found it a bit difficult to get the belt installed in one-piece grippers so I made one that uses screws to clamp the belt securely. M3x10 screws are recommended, 4 required per axis. The gripper must be mirrored for the Y axis.

Use at your own risk - I am not responsible for any injury or damage, etc.
Print in ABS at 100% infill. I use an RC car body reamer to put a slight bevel on the holes to make it easier for the screws to bite.
Mirror the main gripper part for the Y axis.
I printed the clamp parts laying flat at 0.1mm layer height, and the gripper block sitting upside down at 0.2mm layer height.
For assembly, I clamped the tensioner-side first, then fed the belt through (this design also allows for the 'mobius' belt configuration) and then held the belt tight while tightening the screws on the second clamp.
Enjoy!

For those of you who remember it, this is the Sega Genesis that came out in 1989. 16 Bit awesome is what it was when it came out. If you print one, please let me see it.  The vent panel isn't complete, it is damaged, I might fix it in the future, but I don't really feel like it at the moment.  The model is water tight so it should be able to be printed.

Tell me how it works out, my printer hasn't arrived yet.
Edit:  If you have access to a program called Topogun, you could use it to create a much lower poly version of this model.  It can use a refrence mesh (This sega genesis .obj file) and you can wrap another mesh around it like shrinkwrap. The resulting mesh is much lower in poly count, it allows you to create all the proper edge loops etc.  We don't have it yet, but we got the scanner for use with 3d animation and we need to use that program to re do the topology of the meshes we are going to animate so they are manageable in 3dsmax

comments.text: I used a Nextengine 3d Scanner HD.  When I bought this thing, I thought I was going to be able to use it just like a photocopier.    What I got was an 8 lb box shaped like an Xbox on its side that has to be used with a tri-pod, crazy angling and it all has to be done at a focal point of 6.5 inches away from the face of this thing.  Then you have to stictch it all together after each scan.  2 days later I have a much better idea of how to actually use the scanner and the realization that this is NOTHING AT ALL like going to Kinko's and putting paper in a machine, pushing copy and walking away.  I'll probably do another one later, I learned half way through this one that I could have used a lower setting to gather the data.  I had to spray the genesis with SKD 2 in order to insure the laser didn't lose data because of the reflective surface and this scanner picked up all the imperfections, that's why it has a painted look to it.  I really want to scan a Han Solo Frozen in Carbonite that we made in clay that was actually used as the gift wrapping for an Ipod Mini, so I tried this first since it is "box shapped".  I think it is going to be hard to get Han Solo scanned.

description.text:
This is a remake(thing:255387) made to work for my j-head clone and to make it fit as neatly as possible on my current printer make:98430).
The other designs seemed to be too long and the mounting system was not what I needed.
If you happen to have this printer and some kind of j-head or j-head-like groove to mount your extruder this should work as long as the length of the extruder is same. I believe is it about 47mm from the bottom of the groove to just before the tip of the extruder.
If you have something else a bit longer or shorter you want to use gimme a shout and I can shorter or lengthen the design.
Almost forgot, this is supposed to be for the Direct Drive Vert Xtruder(thing:137806)
Warning: I have my extruder motor mounted directly to my X-Carriage. 10-21-14 - Added a few pics of the "evolution" of this design. The thing this was remixed from. The first print, then the final proper length for my own J-head. 11-20-14 - Working on a more universal mounting system for this. Also going to redirect a higher percentage of the air flow towards the print instead of 50/50 currently, maybe 30/70. Stay tuned.

This is a hollow conical nose cone design for model rockets. The SCAD file is parametric - change the diameter and ratio (height to diameter) in inches and the program does the rest. Commented in the file are common diameters for nose cones. By using ratios, you can easily up or down scale any elliptical nose cone design for any diameter. Also included are three nose cone designs ready to print. See the instructions for favorite nose cone ratios. Please note - the NC-55BB nose cone is 8" tall including shoulder - make sure your printer can handle that size object.

Simply change the diameter and ratio (in inches) in the OPENSCAD file for the nose cone you want to print and the file will create it.
Some common and favorite elliptical nose cones are:
NC-5S - 2.77
NC-20R - 3.74 (WAC Corporal Nose Cone)
NC-50AR - 5.12 (has about a 1/2" cylindrical section - lengthen body tube of design by 1/2" to compensate)
NC-55BB - 4.91 (Black Brant II)

Design award winner in the 1992 NYC International Contemporary Furniture Fair for excellence in design. Link to Randy Castellon's about.me;
http://about.me/randycastellon_makerstudio

comments.text:
I am sure it is a great program (I almost was inclined to pony up and buy it, but I have other things I want to buy)
that being said, I kind of have this push to using free software whenever possible. and I am on a bit of a mission
to get others to try to model for themselves. So sculptris being free is a really good fit.
It has it's issues, but it has a fairly short learning curve (compared to many other programs)
these "starter" models are my attempt t get folks to try it out and get results they are proud of
without pulling their hair out!
Make human was the base of many of my figures like the fairy, vamprella and a few devils.
It is a great starting point to someone who knows how to clean them up.
meshmaker is another freebie that can "fix" them easily.
as a perl programmer I know was fond of saying "there's more than one way to do it."

description.text:
This is a marker for tabletop gaming. I made it for a specific challenge during a Warmachine season, but it can work for nearly any tabletop game.  
It's sitting on a 120mm base, the same size as a Warmachine/Hordes collosal, but can be scaled (relatively) easily to fit whatever size marker you're in search of.

Print (with support on). Paint. Base. It's that simple. Well... mostly.
My painted model was printed at .3mm layer height, and suffered from a shifting Y axis. The end result was a skull that looked quite a bit like it was made from slate. Even without a shifting Y axis, larger layer heights should be useful for this effect.
The unpainted model was printed at .1mm layer height, and printed perfectly. This comes out looking more like a skull, and gives a better look on the flanking crystals.
So that's your choice: Shale, or smooth rock.

title: drainers for bottles (bottle -> cup & bottle -> bottle)

description.text:
Ever tried to completely drain a bottle with a low viscous fluid (e.g. silicone -> expensive!)?
print it - srew it on - put it on a cup or another bottle and let it drain

outer diameter of bottle thread: 26.65mm
inner thread diameter: 24,4mm
thread pitch: 4mm
thread length: 13mm (25mm for bottle-bottle) groove for cup (bottle to cup version):
outer: 91mm
inner: 81mm If you're asking yourself why I designed 2 parts instead of one which fullfils both jobs: if I would have made the thread of the bottle->cup 25mm you would have drops of your liquid in the thread when draining in a cup... ;-)

Take care if you have a 2 compound Silicone / fluid as I have: NEVER mix the drainers as your liquid my starting to cure.
...print 2 and mark them properly....

title: MIcroquad scrab
license: Creative Commons - Attribution - Non-Commercial - Share Alike

description.text:
This is a micro quad full designed to improve the better FPV experience, and also a good video recording.
The arms are designed to protect motors and offers a good resistance to the impact and protecting the cables. I have two designs, up to 28mm motor and 5 inch prop, and up to 24mm motor and 6 inch prop.
The ESC are placed inside the body, protecting them and ofering a good air flow. Few wires goes out from body: battery, 4 signals, and 5v Vcc.
And the best of the design is the free vibration area, at the top, too large to place the naze32 (or similar), receiver, video transmitter, FPV camera and HD recording camera (and also an OSD).
Here you can see a video recordered with this quad: http://youtu.be/sghRsG60mQE
The hardware you need is up to 16 screws M2x20mm, up to 4 M2x14, and 4 antivibration balls (50-65 grs) from hobbiking (blue or black ones) Edit: Another video recordered with this quad: http://youtu.be/7uF6bPYqLfo I also have a micro-tri and a micro-hexa versions I'll upload soon

Once you have printed, sand the sides of the arms, only the part must be inserted into the body.
Place the nuts using a solder at the bottom of the middle body. You can uso 4 screws in all arms or only 2, IMO with 2 screws is enougth hard.
Mount 4 arms with middle body and top body and screw them together.
Place motors in the arm, and the ESC and solder them.
Put the antivibration balls in the top plate and join it with the main body.
Before placing the botom cover, place a velcro to secure the lipo between top plate and main body.

description.text:
UPDATE 2/12/17. This part was used in the Ghostbusters Station 6 fan film. Check it out on youtube at https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=RHMUsQqLmRg A full size, 3Dprintable gearbox for Ghostbuster Proton Pack based
on Steffan Otto's plans at:
http://www.gbfans.com/wiki/Stefan_Otto%27s_Prop_Plans There are other versions of this, but they are very wasteful of plastic as the entire body needs to be filled. Also, the rounded 'gear housing' at the top is printed
orthogonally to
the radius axis to give a smoother finish. Print the attached gearbox.pdf at 'Acutal Size' to get a plan of the
drill centres to mount it on the motherboard. Use six #4 screws to
fasten it.
Attach the top part to the bottom using four #4 x 5/8" self tappers, or use epoxy glue. Print GearboxGearHousing with 100% infill for strength when
attaching ribbed tube. Use epoxy glue to fasten GearboxgearHousing to GearBoxTop. It will probably need slightly sanding to help it fit. UPDATE: 23/10/14 Gearbox bottom walls thickened by 3mm. If you downloaded before this date, please print and glue wallbooster.stl to reinforce wall that mounts HGA.
UPDATE: 2/11/2014. The hole used to mount the HGA has been
raised slightly to prevent the HGA fouling the motherboard corner:
http://www.thingiverse.com/thing:526108
UPDATE: 6/11/14. Inverted GearboxBottom as it was not printable.
UPDATE: 13/11/14. Added missing detail to the top of the gearbox.
